Posts.Content: Dijn, what you cite from the study had been found by Haffner too: Tracking the clonal origin of lethal prostate cancer G24
Posts.Title: Multifocal PCa: Prostate vs Metastatic lesions

Posts.Content: I think radiation oncologists try to avoid mentioning adjuvant ADT because they are afraid they may loose patients if they tell them that this is required. The guidelines recommend ADT and that is standard of care. You can get away with 18 months of ADT according to this study: Nabid 2018-Duration of Androgen Deprivation Therapy
Posts.Title: Lupron and on and on?

Posts.Content: I think radiation oncologists try to avoid mentioning adjuvant ADT because they are afraid they may loose patients if they tell them that this is required. Posts.Title: Lupron and on and on?

Posts.Content: Hi PFS, this is a low risk cancer, you do not need to be afraid to die from it. This are your main options: - Active surveillance = watch how things develop and have a control biopsy in a years time. So no impotency nor incontinence. - Surgery = will most likely cure you. If you choose an excellent clinic you have the best chances not to become incontinent or impotent. - Radiation = avoids surgery, similar anti-tumor results compared with surgery. There is a famous radiation center in Sarrasota - Dr. Dattoli
Posts.Title: What to do?

Posts.Title: What to do?

Posts.Content: Michael, when the cancer has spread it cannot be cured. Zapping visible mets with Cyberknife is just a different way to delay the progression of the tumor. It saves you from ADT while you are oligometastatic. As I said, last year I had all the visible recurrences radiated with Cyberknife and after one year following that have at least five new mets now. I knew I would get new ones but I did not expect that many. I will see if they will radiate these again. Keep my fingers crossed. I will probably add ADT this time. The RO said, the visible recurrences would be controlled without ADT. Yes, the visible ones were controlled but new ones appeared. And these can appear in areas difficult to radiate. G24

Posts.Title: Free Randomized Clinical Trial of Ga-68-PSMA-11 PET indicator at UCLA

Posts.Content: With your Gleason 9, seminal vesicle involvement, multiple positive margins and Stage T3b you should really start ADT after radiation. See this review. They report that ADT is beneficial for high risk patients. G24
Posts.Title: Post surgery and RT: recurrence possiblities?

Posts.Content: RobLee, the results of this trial are published as: "no benefit for adding Mitoxantrone". However, as you observed, the really interesting results are based on the control arm. Nobody expected that high-risk patients would have such a benefit from two years of ADT [CAB] right after surgery. Tanja Dorff published interim results of this trial and discussed these results of the control arm in detail: Adjuvant Androgen Deprivation for High-Risk Prostate Cancer After Radical Prostatectomy: SWOG S9921 Study G24
Posts.Title: Gleason 9, PSA 23

Posts.Content: Tim, I agree with your surgeon, if you have a Gleason 9 you have a high risk of recurrence. On the other hand, if 24 lymph nodes are clear, you may not recur. As long as your testosterone is low and you did not get resistant to ADT, your PSA stays low. If you interrupt the ADT e.g. now, after about a year the testosterone will recover and your PSA value will probably rise. But you can live with that, a PSA value will not kill you. I understand that you are having ADT now. Since you are high risk, it is correct to combine the radiation with ADT. Here is a trial that shows how long high risk patients will live if they had two years of ADT after surgery. Most of them well over ten years. G24
Posts.Title: Gleason 9, PSA 23

Posts.Content: The newest and perhaps most accurate PSMA-based PET indicator, F(18 )-PSMA-1007, is in clinical trials in Germany (see this link). Well, there is no link. I had a F-18-PSMA-1007 PET/MRI beginning of last month in Germany. Did not like what they found, five new lymph node mets plus two in question. They told me F-18-PSMA-1007 just a little bit better, regarding contrast if I recall correctly, than a Ga68-PSMA PET/MRI or CT. I had a F-18-DCFPyL PSMA PET/CT last year in Cologne. The RO was surprised that I thought F-18-DCFPyL would be better than a Ga68-PSMA PET/CT. Following that had the visible mets zapped with Cyberknife. Seems to be a "Hare and hedgehog" game now. G24
Posts.Title: Free Randomized Clinical Trial of Ga-68-PSMA-11 PET indicator at UCLA

Posts.Content: If you are PSMA negative, you can try one of these tracers: "In those prostate cancers that do not express PSMA, alternative tracers using choline, fluciclovine or fluorodeoxyglucose, may be of utility." Cited from: Radiotherapy for recurrent prostate cancer: 2018 Recommendations of the Australian and New Zealand Radiation Oncology Genito-Urinary group However, you probably need a much higher PSA value for these tracers to work. G24
Posts.Title: PSMA scan
